(I hope I've got the levels of attribution right. It was all
messed up when I received it, and I had to
reformat/teconstruct it.)

A phonetician's two worthless coins: It is a well-known fact
that the vowels in _father, lot_ and _caught_ merge in North
American English. The _father-lot_ merger is almost general
in North America, with the exception of some (most?)
Southern accents, and the_lot-caught_ merger is general
among younger (than about 40 y.o.) speakers, and has been
general in Canada for several generations. See "Phonological
history of English low back vowels" in Wikipedia
<http://tinyurl.com/vwbll>, and "Phonological history of
English vowels" <http://tinyurl.com/wzygh> for a more
general overview of changes in English vowels. (I use
tinyurls because the full WP URLs are very long, and get
broken across lines.)

(When discussing these things it is useful to refer to
the lexical sets proposed by John C. Wells (see
<http://tinyurl.com/y8jczq>, <http://tinyurl.com/y6jo2w>,
<http://tinyurl.com/y6p6kq>. They are not enough for
dialects with /l/-vocalization
<http://tinyurl.com/tdnul>, however.)

How then are we to handle such variation when writing QS? It
is clear that Read expected QS orthography to be supra-
dialectal, a fact most evident in the fact that he expected
everyone to write _r_ before consonants and at the end of
words, even though most Englishmen -- probably including
Read himself -- haven't pronounced /r/ in this position for
centuries. Obviously if we find it reasonable to expect
people who speak 'r-dropping' dialects to write all
historical _r_s in QS then it is just as reasonable to
expect people who speak dialects that merge the three
historical low back vowels to distinguish these when writing
QS -- especially since these dialects are essentially
complementary: *everyone* from both major dialect groups
will have to make some effort to preserve in spelling some
distinctions lost in their own speech but preserved in the
other major dialect group. Another such trait is the merger
of /t/ and /d/ between vowels in many dialects.

BTW the trouble is probably greater for speakers of
Australian and Estuary English <http://tinyurl.com/yycd2n>,
who have a whole new set of vowels due to the vocalization
of /l/ after vowels, similar to the much earlier
vocalization of /r/; they would need a somewhat largish set
of new vowel letters to write phonetically, rather than just
disregard some distinctions which QS provides for.

It is probably a good thing for the reference dialect(s)
underlying an orthography to be somewhat conservative, since
the actual pronunciations in less conservative dialects can
usually be described in terms of conditioned splits and
mergers compared to the reference dialect(s). The problem
with traditional English orthography is that it is far too
conservative, reflecting the pronunciation of half a
millennium ago. In speech change goes on unabated, and even
the phonemic analysis used by Read will be too conservative
one day, but as long as we want to think that the present
English dialects of Britain, the Southern Hemisphere and
North America are indeed a single language, it remains a
useful compromise.

Paul Vandenbrink skrev:
> Hi Tim It's the same for me. It is hard to distinguish,
> the short "ah" or "on" sound from the similar but longer
> "aw" sound in "haul", as I speak with an American accent.
> Actually I tend to use the "aw" letter a lot and restrict
> "on" to shorter vowel sounds in-between 2 consonants. For
> example, Doc, hot, bottle, talk, rot and got.
>
> As for the Schwa sound, it is 90% of the time very very
> short. I would mind having a letter for the longer soft
> "u" sound, but it is so rare, that it doesn't cause a
> lot of confusion to lump the 2 sounds together under
> one letter.

tim_rice09@... wrote:
>> Well, the vowels for hawk and hock in my and many others
>> speech areone and the same. Though I still write them
>> differently inQuickscript. My dialect also has only one
>> schwa sound, which was oneof the reasons I chose
>> Quickscript over Shavian.Despite its drawbacks,
>> Quicksript is the best alternative to Orthodoxwriting I
>> have found so far.
>>

pgabhart wrote:
>>> Tim: I am curious, does your dialect distinguish between
>>> the vowels of"hock" and "hawk"? Although I pronounce
>>> "on" with Awe as you would, I would use Ox for "hock."
>>> What phoneme would you use for what one does at a pawn
>>> shop? Paige
>>>

tim_rice09 wrote:
>>>> If the rules and spellings recommended in the
>>>> Quickscript Manual are to be disregarded, please,
>>>> whatever you do, do not proclaim it the standard. I am
>>>> not accusing anyone of doing that but intend this to be
>>>> a warning to save Quickscript from what condemned
>>>> Orthodox writing and made many other reform alphabets
>>>> unappealing. The Senior contractions in the Manual save
>>>> incalculable time and space but take about a month to
>>>> master, these I would like kept. As for me I'll keep
>>>> using the full alphabet, even though my dialect
>>>> (General American) uses only the Awe sound for the Ox
>>>> letter it comes in handy to distinguish say Walk from
>>>> Wok. And has no Why sound.
--
